author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum has recently seen more and more blocks where the fees are higher than the block reward, and 1559 solves that issue.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, even if we ignore all of the economic arguments for 1559, I think the *BIGGER* argument in favor of 1559 is the UX benefit it provides to users.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right now, in order to get a transaction mined as cheaply as possible you must be an expert at predicting future congestion.  This is a *really* hard problem and so far no one has come up with a mechanism of solving it with 100% accuracy.  1559 makes it so *users* (regular people, not experts) can reliably get a transaction included for as cheap as possible without needing to do anything complicated.

author: sky.cactus
content: One of the biggest complaints across all dapp users is frustration around pending transactions, inclusion delays, stuck transactions, etc.  This is all a symptom of the way gas price auctions work.  1559 *mostly* solves those problems.

Currently, if you set a high gas price you always pay the max.
With 1559 if you set a high fee cap you pay the min.

author: timbeiko
content: That changes under 1559: we go from ~never having room for marginal transaction (e.g. full mempool) to ~always having room, except in periods which a rapid spike in demand. The reason for this is that having the `base fee` makes it clear which txns can be included and which aren't valid. So, in the average case, users' transactions will be included in the next block or two, at the "right" gas price rather than by paying a huge fee.

author: timbeiko
content: Some users will still want to pay a huge fee to be *sure* to be included in the next block, and miners will still get those fees.

author: timbeiko
content: Also, L2 helps with decreasing the transaction fees. 1559 doesn't claim to do that: it just makes it explicit what the "right price" is, regardless of whether that price is high or low. It may result in a slight lowering of prices because of better estimation, but it won't drastically lower fees.

author: pietjepuk
content: To me it seems like the obvious solution to the terrible UX of first-price auctions. I don't really get all this "burning fees will make ETH moon" stuff (from proponents or opponents); it's rather negligible to block rewards, and definitely negligible to block reward reductions in the past (5 -> 3 -> 2 ETH). Ethereum is also not the first to implement this 1559-style fee scheme, it's already out there being used by other chains.

author: pietjepuk
content: The remaining "but it's new code, it might break consensus"-argument holds equally well for eth1 as for eth2. I don't see how waiting until eth2 will reduce the exposure to that risk. It may certainly feel that way, because for eth2 it will be compounded with more risks of all the other changes that eth2 brings. That does also hold for eth1 to some extent though, as it's likely not the only change included in a hard fork.

author: pietjepuk
content: In other words, when it's done and tested, might as well roll it out (being on eth1 or eth2, whichever it happens to be at that time)

author: timbeiko
content: That's the plan! We're doing extensive testing right now, and have both a theoretical analysis and simulations that all point towards 1559 working as intended.

author: timbeiko
content: My hunch is we'll have 1559 fully implemented by the end of Q1, assuming our last round of performance testing on clients works. Then, we'll still have work to do to make it "ready for mainnet" (cross-client acceptance tests, auxiliary EIPs for the JSON RPC bits that change, documentation, etc.), but the heavy lifting will be done.
